description: In classical architecture, the main horizontal beam resting directly on the capitals of columns, supporting the frieze and cornice.
The uppermost horizontal molded projection that crowns a building or wall.
An arched structure, usually of stone, brick, or concrete, serving to cover a space.
A sculptural technique where the sculpted elements remain attached to a solid background of the same material.
A technique of mural painting executed upon freshly laid ('wet') lime plaster.
A style or technique (as in music, literature, or design) that is characterized by extreme spareness and simplicity.

A style of modernist architecture that flourished from the 1950s to the mid-1970s, characterized by its massive, monolithic and 'blocky' appearance with a rigid geometric style and large-scale use of poured concrete.
Architecture that seeks to minimize the negative environmental impact of buildings by efficiency and moderation in the use of materials, energy, and development space and the ecosystem at large.
The principal front of a building, that faces on to a street or open space.
A design plan or other technical drawing.
